{{Infobox figure skater |name= John Baldwin |image= John baldwin skater.jpg |caption= Rena Inoue and John Baldwin |fullname= John Baldwin, Jr. |country= [[United States of America|United States]] |birth_date= {{Birth date and age|1973|10|18}} |residence= [[Santa Monica, California|Santa Monica]], [[California]] |height= {{convert|175|cm|ft|abbr=on}} |weight= |partner= '''[[Rena Inoue]]''' |formerpartner=[[Tristan Colell]] |coach= [[Jenni Meno]] & [[Todd Sand]] |formercoach= [[Philipp Mills]]
[[Peter Oppegard]]
[[Oksana Grishuk]]
[[Jill Watson]] |choreographer= |formerchoreographer= [[Oksana Grishuk]]
[[Philipp Mills]] |skating club= All Year FSC |retired = |combined total= 183.17 |combined date= [[2006 World Figure Skating Championships|2006 Worlds]] |SP score= 61.73 |SP date= [[2007 Four Continents]] |FS score= 122.27 |FS date= [[2006 World Figure Skating Championships|2006 Worlds]] |medaltemplates= {{MedalCountry | [[United States of America|United States]] }} {{MedalSport | Pairs [[Figure skating]]}} {{MedalCompetition|[[Four Continents Figure Skating Championships|Four Continents Championships]]}} {{MedalGold|[[2006 Four Continents Figure Skating Championships|2006 Colorado Springs]]|[[2006 Four Continents Figure Skating Championships|Pairs]]}} {{MedalBronze|[[2007 Four Continents Figure Skating Championships|2007 Colorado Springs]]|[[2007 Four Continents Figure Skating Championships|Pairs]]}} }} '''John Baldwin, Jr.''' (born October 18, 1973 in [[Dallas, Texas]]) is an [[United States|American]] [[Figure skating|figure skater]]. With partner [[Rena Inoue]], he is a two-time [[United States Figure Skating Championships|U.S. national champion]]. Inoue and Baldwin are the first skaters to perform a [[axel jump|throw triple axel]] in competition. ==Personal life== Baldwin comes from a family of skaters. His father, John Baldwin Sr, competed as a single skater in the 1960s. His brother Don Baldwin competed in singles as well. Baldwin proposed to his skating partner [[Rena Inoue]] in January 2008. ==Career== John Baldwin originally competed in both singles and pairs. With partner [[Tristan Colell]], he competed at the [[World Junior Figure Skating Championships]]. Baldwin was a veteran single skater, having competed at every national championship from his win at the novice level in 1987 through 2000. His best finish at Nationals as a senior was 9th in 1995. His father, who was a skating coach, arranged a tryout between Baldwin and [[Rena Inoue]], a Japanese skater living in America. Inoue and Baldwin tried out and agreed to form the partnership. They began competing together in 2000. They placed 11th at the [[2001 U.S. Figure Skating Championships]]. The following season, they won the pewter medal at the [[2002 U.S. Figure Skating Championships]]. They were sent to the [[2002 Four Continents Championships]], their first international competition together, and placed 7th. In the 2002-2003 season, they competed on the Grand Prix. Returning to Nationals, they won the bronze medal. They withdrew from the [[2003 Four Continents Championships]], but placed 10th at the [[2003 World Figure Skating Championships]]. In the 2003-2004 season, they improved on their Grand Prix results and won their first national title. They placed 4th at the [[2004 Four Continents Championships]] and repeated their 10th place finish at the [[2004 World Figure Skating Championships]]. In the 2004-2005 season, they medaled for the first time on the Grand Prix and qualified for the Grand Prix Final, where they placed 6th. They won the silver medal at the [[2005 U.S. Figure Skating Championships]] and placed 11th at the [[2005 World Figure Skating Championships]]. In the 2005-2006 season, Inoue and Baldwin medaled on the Grand Prix. At the [[2006 U.S. Figure Skating Championships]], Inoue and Baldwin became the first pair to successfully perform a throw triple [[Axel jump|Axel]] in competition.{{cite news| url=http://www.usatoday.com/sports/olympics/winter/2006-01-13-pairs-free-skate_x.htm | work=USA Today | first1=Gary | last1=Mihoces | title=A first in pairs skating? | date=26 January 2006}} They went on to the [[2006 Four Continents Championships]], which they won. At the [[2006 Winter Olympics]], they made Olympic and international history when they landed the throw triple axel for the first time in international competition. They placed 7th overall. At the [[2006 World Figure Skating Championships]], they placed 4th. [[Image:2006 Skate America Pairs Podium.jpg|thumb|right|Inoue and Baldwin on the podium at the 2006 Skate America.]] In the 2006-2007 season, Inoue and Baldwin won the gold medal at the [[2006 Skate America]] after winning the short program and placing second in the free skate. They won the silver medal at [[2006 Skate Canada International]] the next week; and then won the silver at [[2006 TrophÃ©e Eric Bompard]] one week later. They qualified for the [[Grand Prix of Figure Skating Final|Grand Prix Final]], and while in St. Petersburg for that competition, Baldwin was abducted, assaulted and robbed,{{Citation| last=Elliott | first=Helene | title=Mugging leaves Baldwin recovering but still shaken | newspaper=The Los Angeles Times |date=23 January 2007| url=http://articles.latimes.com/2007/jan/23/sports/sp-elliott23 | accessdate=February 16, 2010}} though he and Inoue were still able to compete, and finished fourth. At the [[2007 U.S. Figure Skating Championships]], they won the silver medal. They placed 8th at the [[2007 World Figure Skating Championships]]. In the 2007-2008 season, Inoue and Baldwin sat out the Grand Prix series, choosing to skate in shows instead. Returning to competition at the [[2008 U.S. Figure Skating Championships]], they won the silver medal. While they were taking their bows following their free skate, Baldwin proposed marriage to Rena on the ice and she accepted.[http://articles.latimes.com/2008/feb/02/sports/sp-elliott2 After their skate, the answer is yes - Los Angeles Times][http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20174124,00.html Olympic Skaters Get Engaged on Ice][http://www.signonsandiego.com/sports/20080127-9999-1s27zeigler.html Baldwin wins Inoue's heart with proposal] Inoue and Baldwin competed at the [[2008 World Figure Skating Championships]], where they placed 10th. Inoue and Baldwin were assigned to the [[2008 Skate America]], where they placed 5th, and the [[2008 NHK Trophy]], where they won the silver medal, for the 2008-2009 Grand Prix Season. ==Competitive highlights== ===Pairs career=== (with Inoue) {| class="wikitable" |- !
